Module nl.naturalis.common
Package nl.naturalis.check

Class CommonChecks

java.lang.Object
nl.naturalis.check.CommonChecks
public final class CommonChecks extends Object
Defines various common checks on arguments, variables, object state, etc. The checks have short, informative error messages associated with them, so you don't have to invent them yourself. Unless specified otherwise, they only test what they are documented to be testing. They will not do a preliminary null check. If the argument might be null, always start with the notNull() check. Otherwise, a raw, unprocessed NullPointerException will be thrown from the check itself, rather than the application code. 

 Check.notNull(file).is(readable());

For ease of reading, the documentation for the checks will use the term "argument" for the value being tested, but it might just as well be a local variable, a field, a program argument, a system property, etc.

Author:
Ayco Holleman

    • yes

      public static Predicate<Boolean> yes()
      Verifies that a condition evaluates to true. If the condition is expressed as a Boolean rather than a boolean, use nullOr(). 
      
 Check.that(list.isEmpty()).is(yes());
      Returns:
      a function implementing the test described above

    • no

      public static Predicate<Boolean> no()
      Verifies that a condition evaluates to false. If the condition is expressed as a Boolean rather than a boolean, use nullOr().
      Returns:
      a function implementing the test described above

    • empty

      public static <T> Predicate<T> empty()
      Verifies that the argument is empty as per ObjectMethods::isEmpty. Possibly more useful when called from an isNot method. 
      
 Check.that(list).isNot(empty());

      This check performs an implicit null check, so can be safely executed without (or instead of) executing the notNull() check first.

      Type Parameters:
      T - the type of the argument
      Returns:
      a function implementing the test described above

    • deepNotNull

      public static <T> Predicate<T> deepNotNull()
      Verifies that the argument is deep-not-null as per ObjectMethods::isDeepNotNull.

      This check performs an implicit null check, so can be safely executed without (or instead of) executing the notNull() check first.

      Type Parameters:
      T - the type of the argument
      Returns:
      a function implementing the test described above
      See Also:
      • ObjectMethods.isDeepNotNull(Object)

      Returns:
      a function implementing the test described above

    • EQ

      public static <X, Y> Relation<X,Y> EQ()
      Verifies that a value equals another value. Equivalent to Objects::equals.
      Type Parameters:
      X - The type of the argument
      Returns:
      a function implementing the test described above

    • GT

      public static <X extends Comparable<X>> Relation<X,X> GT()
      Verifies that the argument is greater than another value. This is the "big brother" of the gt() check and specifically enables to validation of non-int primitive numbers and primitive number wrappers (including Integer). However, it can be used to check any value that is an instance of Comparable.
      Type Parameters:
      X - The type of the values being compared
      Returns:
      a function implementing the test described above
      See Also:
      • CommonProperties.unbox()
      • gt()

    • LT

      public static <X extends Comparable<X>> Relation<X,X> LT()
      Verifies that the argument is less than another value. This is the "big brother" of the lt() check and specifically enables to validation of non-int primitive numbers and primitive number wrappers (including Integer). However, it can be used to check any value that is an instance of Comparable.
      Type Parameters:
      X - The type of the values being compared
      Returns:
      a function implementing the test described above
      See Also:
      • CommonProperties.unbox()
      • lt()

    • GTE

      public static <X extends Comparable<X>> Relation<X,X> GTE()
      Verifies that the argument is greater than or equal to another value. This is the "big brother" of the gte() check and specifically enables to validation of non-int primitive numbers and primitive number wrappers (including Integer). However, it can be used to check any value that is an instance of Comparable.
      Type Parameters:
      X - The type of the values being compared
      Returns:
      a function implementing the test described above
      See Also:
      • CommonProperties.unbox()
      • gte()

      public static <X extends Comparable<X>> Relation<X,X> LTE()
      Verifies that the argument is less than or equal to another value. This is the "big brother" of the lte() check and specifically enables to validation of non-int primitive numbers and primitive number wrappers (including Integer). However, it can be used to check any value that is an instance of Comparable.
      Type Parameters:

    • supertypeOf

      public static <T, U> Relation<Class<T>,Class<U>> supertypeOf()
      Verifies that the argument is a supertype of another type. In other words, that the other type extends, implements, or is equal to the argument. Equivalent to ClassMethods::isSupertype.
      Returns:
      A Relation that implements the test described above

    • subtypeOf

      public static <T, U> Relation<Class<T>,Class<U>> subtypeOf()
      Verifies that the argument is a subtype of another type. In other words, that it extends or implements the other type. Equivalent to Class, Class) ClassMethods::isSubtype
      Returns:
      A Relation that implements the test described above

      public static <Y, X extends Y> Relation<X,Y[]> inArray()
      Verifies that the argument is an element of an array. Equivalent to ArrayMethods::isElementOf.
      Type Parameters:

      Returns:
      a function implementing the test described above

    • enclosing

      public static <E, C0 extends Collection<? super E>, C1 extends Collection<E>> Relation<C0,C1> enclosing()
      Verifies that a Collection argument contains all the elements of the specified collection. Equivalent to Collection::containsAll. 
      
 Check.that(List.of(1,2,3)).is(enclosing(), Set.of(1,2); // true
 Check.that(List.of(1,2)).is(enclosing(), Set.of(1,2,3); // false
      Type Parameters:
      E - The type of the elements in the Collection
      C0 - The type of the argument (the subject of the Relation)
      C1 - The type of the object of the Relation
      Returns:
      a function implementing the test described above

    • enclosedBy

      public static <E, C0 extends Collection<E>, C1 extends Collection<? super E>> Relation<C0,C1> enclosedBy()
      Verifies that a Collection argument is a subset or sublist of another Collection. 
      
 Check.that(List.of(1,2,3)).is(enclosedBy(), Set.of(1,2); // false
 Check.that(List.of(1,2)).is(enclosedBy(), Set.of(1,2,3); // true
      Type Parameters:
      E - The type of the elements in the Collection
      C0 - The type of the argument (the subject of the Relation)
      C1 - The type of the object of the Relation
      Returns:
      a function implementing the test described above

    • containingString

      public static Relation<String,CharSequence> containingString()
      Verifies that the argument contains the specified substring. Equivalent to String::contains.
      Returns:
      a function implementing the test described above

    • substringOf

      public static Relation<String,String> substringOf()
      Verifies that the argument is a substring of the specified string.
      Returns:
      a function implementing the test described above

    • equalsIgnoreCase

      public static Relation<String,String> equalsIgnoreCase()
      Verifies that a value equals ignoring case the specified string.

      public static Relation<String,String> endsWith()
      Verifies that the argument ends with the specified substring. Equivalent to String::endsWith.
      Returns:
      a function implementing the test described above

    • indexOf

      public static <T> IntObjRelation<T> indexOf()
      Verifies that the argument is a valid index into the specified array, List or String. No preliminary check is done to ensure the provided object actually is an array, List or String. An InvalidCheckException is thrown if it is not. Execute the instanceOf() or array() check first, if necessary.
      Type Parameters:
      T - the type of the object of the IntObjRelation - must be a String, List or array
      Returns:
      a function implementing the test described above

    • indexInclusiveOf

      public static <T> IntObjRelation<T> indexInclusiveOf()
      Verifies that a value can be used as a "from" or "to" index in operations like (but not limited to) Arrays.copyOfRange, String.substring and List.subList. These operations allow both the "from" index and the "to" index to be equal to the length of the array, string or list. No preliminary check is done to ensure the provided object actually is an array, List or String. An InvalidCheckException is thrown if it is not. Execute the instanceOf() or array() check first, if necessary.
      Type Parameters:
      T - the type of the object of the IntObjRelation - must be a String, List or array
      Returns:
      a function implementing the test described above
      See Also:
      • Check.fromTo(Object[], int, int)

    • inRangeOf

      public static IntObjRelation<int[]> inRangeOf()
      Verifies that the argument is greater than, or equal to the first integer in the provided int array, and less than the second. This check can be made more concise using ArrayMethods.ints: 
      
 Check.that(age).is(inRangeOf(), ints(15, 65));
      Returns:
      a function implementing the test described above

    • between

      public static IntObjRelation<int[]> between()
      Verifies that the argument is greater than, or equal to the first integer in the provided int array, and less than, or equal to the second (like the SQL BETWEEN operator). This check can be made more concise using ArrayMethods.ints: 
      
 Check.that(age).is(between(), ints(15, 65));
      Returns:
      a function implementing the test described above

    • inIntArray

      public static IntObjRelation<int[]> inIntArray()
      Verifies that the argument is present in the specified int array. Equivalent to ArrayMethods::isElementOf.
      Returns:
      a function implementing the test described above
